title: The embodied brain: Bridging the brain, body, and behavior with neuromechanical digital twins
abstract: 动物行为反映了神经系统、躯体与环境之间的相互作用。因此，解析行为控制算法必须考虑生物力学与环境背景。神经力学数字孪生技术为此提供了可能——该技术通过在模拟环境中将人工神经控制器嵌入逼真的躯体模型来构建计算模型。本文回顾了神经力学数字孪生技术的创建与应用进展，并展望其未来发展的新机遇。首先，我们阐释神经力学模型如何帮助研究者推断实验中难以测量的潜在生物物理变量；通过扰动这些模型，研究者还能生成可供实验验证的新假设。其次，我们探讨神经力学数字孪生如何深化神经科学、机器人学与机器学习领域的交叉融合。最后，我们展示该技术在医疗健康领域的应用前景。我们预见，将动物研究与对其神经力学数字孪生的主动探测相结合，将极大加速神经科学领域的发现进程。

Highlights
•
Neuromechanical digital twins comprise a neural controller and a biomechanical hull
•
Replaying experimental recordings
in silico
enables readout of latent variables
•
Simulations help to test neuroscientific hypotheses
•
Simulations provide a fully accessible and perturbable surrogate for behavior control
•
Embodied computational models provide a foundation for NeuroAI

Abstract
Animal behavior reflects interactions between the nervous system, body, and environment. Therefore, biomechanics and environmental context must be considered to dissect algorithms for behavioral control. This is enabled by leveraging neuromechanical digital twins: computational models that embed artificial neural controllers within realistic body models in simulated environments. Here we review advances in the creation and use of neuromechanical digital twins while also highlighting emerging opportunities for the future. First, we illustrate how neuromechanical models allow researchers to infer hidden biophysical variables that may be difficult to measure experimentally. Additionally, by perturbing these models, one can generate new experimentally testable hypotheses. Next, we explore how neuromechanical twins have been used to foster a deeper exchange between neuroscience, robotics, and machine learning. Finally, we show how neuromechanical twins can advance healthcare. We envision that coupling studies on animals with active probing of their neuromechanical twins will greatly accelerate neuroscientific discovery.
Keywords:
Neuromechanical model, biomechanics, digital twin, artificial neural network, sensorimotor control, physics simulation, NeuroAI
Introduction
Animal behaviors cannot be understood in isolation from the body and the environments in which they are expressed
[
20
]
, because they arise from two tightly interconnected feedback loops: one between the nervous system and the body, and the other between the body and external environment. Studying any one component alone, although valuable for addressing specific questions, can only provide a partial view of the integrative whole.
A wide range of experimental tools have been developed to investigate neural circuits (
e.g.
, optogenetics, optical recordings, and electrophysiology), to measure movements of body parts (
e.g.
, motion capture, and machine learning-based pose estimation), and to manipulate environments (
e.g.
, virtual reality). However, these tools face two fundamental limitations. First, there are considerable
practical barriers
to obtaining neuronal recordings. For example, in large animals like primates, it remains challenging to target specific neurons using genetic reagents, and high-density electrode arrays cannot provide information about neuronal identities. Additionally, recordings of muscle physiology can interfere with natural behavior, meaning that the number of muscles that can be recorded simultaneously is limited. Thus, dynamic mechanical variables like joint torques and contact forces can be hard to measure. Second, establishing causality in neuroscience typically requires experimental
perturbations
to conclude, for example, that “the firing of neuron A causes behavior B.” However, most existing neural perturbation approaches are either too local (
e.g.
, optogenetic tools enabling perturbations of small numbers of neurons), or too broad (
e.g.
, pharmacologically or genetically enabled global perturbations based on brain regions or cell types). Patterned manipulation of large numbers of neurons with high specificity is required to test hypotheses regarding higher-level network dynamics, but such experimental capabilities remain mostly out of reach.
Figure 1:
Parallels between real animals and their neuromechanical digital twins.
How physiological, mechanical, and environmental variables can be accessed and manipulated in real animals
(upper half)
, or in digital twins
(lower half)
. Rows on the lower half summarize the full promise of twins, the current status of the approach, and the challenges that need to be overcome to accomplish its full potential. Real datasets that can be used to link these systems are indicated.
Neuromechanical digital twins provide an alternative, complementary framework to address these technical challenges in measurements and perturbations. These models typically consist of a
biomechanical
replica of the body—with varying degrees of morphological realism including joint articulations, muscles and contact dynamics—and a
neural controller
model including motor/premotor circuits and sensory pathways. Together, at least in principle, body and neural controller models form a fully accessible, closed-loop system in which sensorimotor dynamics can be generated, observed, manipulated, and analyzed
(
Figure 1
)
. Because digital twins exist entirely
in silico
, they can be subject to arbitrary perturbations and counterfactual simulations, enabling researchers to ask “what if” questions. Thus, neuromechanical models constitute a complementary approach to
in vivo
experimentation that can bridge the gaps and integrate across multiple levels of biological organization. In fact, the use of simulated body models controlled by artificial neural networks dates back decades, most prominently in the study of insect stick insect and cockroach locomotion
[
3
]
. More recently, advances in simulation throughput and accurate physics
[
48
,
24
]
have enabled the development of more realistic body models, particularly for animal and human neuromechanical simulations
[
50
,
12
,
2
]
, greatly expanding opportunities for afforded by this approach.
Figure 2:
Prior knowledge of biological systems helps infer structure, behavior, and function from limited experimental data.
(Top row)
As an analogy, consider the task of reconstructing a vase based on a partial sketch. Naïvely, we cannot accurately model the shape of the vase using only partial observations. However, if we apply the prior that the vase should be radially symmetric, we can fill in missing regions and consolidate redundant measurements.
(Middle and bottom rows)
Similarly, embedding biologically plausible features (
e.g.
, priors concerning body morphology, musculoskeletal organization, and neural network topology) into the digital twin constrains the solution space and improves reconstruction quality from sparse or noisy experimental data. Since simulated dynamics are fully accessible, this can also greatly extend the amount of information that can be inferred from limited experimental data.
Crucially, neuromechanical digital twins are designed to be constrained by biological features. For example, joint articulation (
e.g.
, the number of degrees of freedom per joint, their ranges of motion, and rotational axes) is based on the anatomy of real animals, and joint movements are subject to passive dynamics including joint damping. Similarly, known neural circuit architecture (
e.g.
, from connectomics) and neuronal properties (
e.g.
, from electrophysiology) can be used to constrain the neural network model. Embedding such prior knowledge into the model as constraints enables more effective and efficient use of limited experimental data. Akin to observing the shape of an object such as a vase from partial outline based on prior knowledge about vases (
e.g.
, symmetry), biologically grounded models improve inference when data are sparse or incomplete
(
Figure 2
)
.
However, serious challenges remain for the use of neuromechanical simulations in neuroscience. For example, artificial neural networks often have unrealistic connectivity or physiological properties. Body models are often approximated using rigid bodies and lack detailed sensory organs and muscle models. Important biomechanical properties, such as actuator gains, are often left as free parameters due to difficulties in obtaining experimental measurements. As well, detailed environmental features and states can be hard to model, especially for behaviors requiring complex body-environment interaction such as flight and swimming. Finally, even when methods for more realistic simulation are available, practical trade-offs exist between realism, computational cost, and implementation complexity. These challenges, as well as the current state of the art in addressing them and required works going forward, are summarized in
Figure 1
and will be discussed in the next sections.
In this article, we will survey recent advances in the development of neuromechanical digital twins and their applications to neuroscience, with a focus on studies published within the past five years while also including older works on simulation infrastructure that are still actively used today and review articles on foundational studies. An overview of the works reviewed is available in
Table 1
. We organize the review along five major themes: (1) inferring unmeasurable variables from experimental data, (2) hypothesis testing by simulating forward-engineered models, (3) studying closed-loop behavior
in silico
, (4) dialog with robotics and the newly emerging field of NeuroAI, and (5) applications in healthcare.

Inference of experimentally unmeasurable variables
One obstacle to understanding how the brain controls behavior is that many variables involved in sensorimotor control are difficult to measure experimentally. For example, internal forces are hard to measure non-invasively, muscle activities are difficult to record at scale, and sensory feedback often can only be recorded indirectly. Neuromechanical digital twins provide a way to predict these variables using only partial experimental data
(
Figure 3
a)
. Typically, this begins with
inverse kinematics
—the process of computing joint angles or body configurations that best reproduce recorded movements—followed by
inverse dynamics
—estimating internal forces required to generate those replayed movements given the mechanical properties of the body. Inferred quantities have included internal forces
[
23
,
28
,
53
]
, muscle activities
[
29
,
13
,
32
,
14
,
43
,
8
]
, sensory feedback
[
51
,
25
,
14
]
, and energy consumption
[
35
]
. These quantities can in turn allow researchers to evaluate behavior in new ways, for example by using contact forces as a proxy for grooming vigor
[
28
]
, and to understand behavior not just kinematically (
i.e.
, using only positions, velocities, etc.), but also dynamically with reference to internal and external forces.
Figure 3:
Two directions for creating a dialogue between animal experiments and neuromechanical simulations.
(
a
) In reverse simulations, one can replay experimental behavioral data
in silico
and use this replay to infer hidden variables like neural and muscle activities that are otherwise difficult to measure. (
b
) Starting from a hypothesized neural circuit, one can roll out behavior
in silico
and compare it with experimental observations.
Beyond biomechanics, an additional opportunity afforded by replaying experimentally recorded behavior is the ability to infer neuromuscular dynamics
in silico
. Estimating muscle dynamics based on kinematic observations is fundamentally difficult because there are typically more muscles than there are joint degrees of freedom. Consequently, in principle, there can be an infinite number of muscle recruitment patterns that can lead to an observed behavior. One approach to combat this challenge is to impose a set of optimization criteria that favor some solutions over others: for example, by minimizing the sum of muscle activations
[
12
]
or the total generated forces
[
32
]
(see in particular the “static optimization” method of OpenSim
[
12
]
). This approach has already provided insights: for instance, by identifying muscle co-activation patterns and suggesting potential muscle synergies
[
29
,
43
]
. A more dynamically constrained approach is to train models that predict the muscle activities needed to replicate observed
sequences
of movements
[
29
,
32
,
10
]
. This is a form of
imitation learning
that we will revisit below.
Because muscles are the main interface between the brain and body biomechanics, muscle dynamics serve as a gateway to probe the inner workings of the nervous system. For example, Marin Vargas
et al.
[
25
]
passively replayed experimentally recorded primate reaching behavior in a musculoskeletal model to test hypothesized roles for proprioception. Because all muscle spindle responses can be accessed
in silico
, the authors were able to train different machine learning models to investigate what information is best encoded in these proprioceptive signals. In another example, Aldarondo
et al.
[
1
]
trained an artificial neural network to imitate recorded rat behaviors in a virtual rodent. The model was then used to replicate the animal’s behavior, effectively acting as an inverse dynamics controller. By comparing activity in the simulated network with recorded neural activity across brain regions, the authors identified candidate regions that may implement inverse dynamics. Neuromechanical twins have also been used to study different sensory modalities beyond mechanosensation. For instance, to study visuomotor behaviors, researchers directly accessed simulated neural activities in the visual system using an artificial neural network constrained by real circuits organization
[
22
,
51
]
.
Testing hypothesized neural controllers through simulation
In the preceding section, we reviewed how neuromechanical models are used to replicate observed behaviors and how readouts from these models can be used to infer physiological variables for the real animal
(
Figure 3
a)
. Conversely, one can also embed a forward-engineered controller into the biomechanical simulation and compare model-controlled behavior with real, experimentally recorded behaviors
(
Figure 3
b)
. Most prominently, biomechanical models have been used to study how locomotion can emerge from centralized oscillators akin to central pattern generators (CPGs)
[
22
,
23
,
27
,
4
]
, decentralized controllers depending on mechanosensory feedback
[
3
,
14
]
, and a combination of the two
[
51
,
33
,
47
]
. Building upon these models, researchers have also investigated how artificial neural controllers can use modulatory signals to modify behavior, for example to perform steering
[
22
,
51
,
4
]
or to fine-tune locomotor gaits (
e.g.
step length, cadence)
[
32
,
14
,
4
]
. Similarly, neuromechanical models have been used to evaluate how timing and synchronization in neural circuits regulate coherent behavior
[
19
,
30
]
.
One unique strength of neuromechanical simulations is the ability to study how the nervous system and the physical body work together. For example, Hoover
et al.
[
18
]
embedded a neuromechanical model within a fluid dynamics simulation to show that the speed of a wave of muscle activation in the jellyfish bell matches the speed at which elastic deformation propagates through the soft material itself. This produces a neuromechanical resonance and enables efficient swimming. Similarly, by replicating recorded behavior in a neuromechanical fly model, Özdil
et al.
[
29
]
demonstrated that passive joint properties like damping facilitate muscle-driven motor control.
Finally, neuromechanical models are also used as a platform to study development, learning, and adaptation in motor control. For instance, Roussel
et al.
[
37
]
modeled putative neural circuits at different zebrafish developmental stages to explain the appearance of distinct swimming patterns. DeWolf
et al.
[
13
]
studied how adult mice learn adaptive movements by replicating recorded behaviors in a body model and reading out postural and muscle-level features. They then modeled how these features might be represented in the brain, identifying how sensorimotor prediction errors might be computed to adapt to unexpected perturbations.
Closing the sensorimotor loop
In the real world, behavior arises from nested feedback loops. For example, the body navigates the environment using senses (
e.g.
, vision, olfaction, and audition) that are consequently modified by self-motion. Simultaneously, the nervous system receives feedback about ongoing low-level movements through proprioception. Embodying neural circuit models within a biomechanical hull in a physics simulator closes the first feedback loop
[
51
,
49
]
while placing models in a sensory-rich environment opens up the opportunity to explore the second feedback loop
[
1
,
19
,
13
,
33
]
. For example, Wang-Chen
et al.
[
51
]
simulated a fly that, controlled by a hierarchical controller, simultaneously performs odor-guided approach and avoidance and vision-guided obstacle navigation while walking over rugged terrain. Similarly, Vaxenburg
et al.
[
49
]
modeled flight in flies using a phenomenological fluid mechanics model, and tasked the fly to to navigate a valley-like corridor based on visual information. In the worm
C. elegans
, Zhao
et al.
[
54
]
combined a brain model with a body model and simulated zigzag movement toward attractors—a behavior that has been previously identified experimentally. These studies highlight how coupled neural and biomechanical models can be used to simulate complex sensorimotor behaviors that resemble those observed in nature.
Simulations also enable the performance of precise perturbations to explore the mechanisms underlying closed loop behaviors such as feedback-based locomotor control, thereby circumventing limitations of real experiments where genetic tools—particularly optogenetic tools—are limited by the availability and specificity of driver lines. For example, taking advantage of the full ability to perturb
in silico
neural controllers and the body itself, Thandiackal
et al.
[
47
]
simulated swimming in a lamprey-based model (as well as using a physical robot) and systematically evaluated the robustness of different hypothesized neural controllers against neuromechanical perturbations including spinal transection.
Finally, recent studies are simulating neural networks with increasing biological fidelity. This includes the use of biologically grounded circuit properties like (i) connectome-constrained artificial neural networks
[
51
,
33
,
40
]
, (ii) experimentally constrained circuit mechanisms
[
55
]
, and (iii) physiologically realistic neuron models
[
31
,
40
]
. For example, Wang-Chen
et al.
[
51
]
fit a neuromechanical model of the fly with a visual system model
[
21
]
based on the real fly’s brain connectome, enabling the inference of biologically plausible visual system responses which were then used to regulate simulated fly-fly chasing. These approaches showcase the synergy between realistic neural network modeling and realistic biomechanical modeling towards the ultimate goal of faithful integration of realistic neural, biomechanical, and environmental dynamics in simulations.
Synergies with Robotics and NeuroAI
Neuroscience and robotics share a long history of mutual interest in understanding how autonomous agents—biological or artificial—are built to behave both flexibly and robustly in complex, unfamiliar environments
[
34
]
. Insights from studying animal behaviors have inspired the design of robots
[
17
,
5
]
, while robots have reciprocally served as physical platforms to test theories of neural control and sensorimotor integration
[
44
,
9
]
. More recently, rapid progress in machine learning has renewed interest in the dialogue between artificial and biological intelligence. The term “NeuroAI” was coined to describe both the development of next-generation AI inspired by neuroscience
[
52
]
and the use of AI systems to evaluate and refine neuroscientific hypotheses
[
39
]
. Neuromechanical models offer a natural bridge between these two areas: machine learning algorithms can be embodied in animal models to test if they can explain observed animal behaviors, and principles enabling biologically realistic neural controllers can be applied to improve AI systems.
The most prominent integration between neuroscience and machine learning has been the use of reinforcement learning to replicate naturalistic behavior in animal body models. A particularly effective approach has been the use of
imitation learning
[
6
,
5
]
, in which an autonomous agent learns from demonstrations rather by trying to achieve an abstract goal. Combined with advances in motion tracking and pose estimation, imitation learning has enabled realistic replication of experimentally recorded behaviors in neuromechanical models
[
1
,
49
,
29
]
.
Another feature of robotic and artificial controllers inspired by neuroscience is the hierarchical organization of information processing by neural controllers: the brain processes and integrates high-level information (
e.g.
, sensory input, memory) and conveys a lower-dimensional representation to motor circuits. Artificial neural controllers can mirror this architecture
[
26
]
. For example, Wang-Chen
et al.
[
51
]
and Vaxenburg
et al.
[
49
]
used models comprising multiple levels of neural processing (
i.e.
, visual system, action selection, low-level motor control) to produce fly behaviors. Returning from artificial systems back to neurobiology, Karashchuk
et al.
[
19
]
simulated a three-stage controller inspired by the anatomical architecture of
Drosophila
motor circuits to investigate how the fly generates robust walking in the presence of sensorimotor delays. Finally, neuromechanical models have also inspired the design of physical robots directly. For instance, decentralized control in a lamprey-based model that enables robust swimming after spinal injury offers a solution for modular robots
[
47
]
, neuromechanical resonance in jellyfish swimming can motivate similar designs in soft-body robots
[
18
]
, and
Drosophila
limb anatomy has informed the design of a hexapod robot
[
17
]
.
Applications in healthcare
The integration of biomechanical models and neurological data also provides a powerful tool to guide neurorehabilitation
[
56
]
, our understanding of diseases
[
41
,
8
]
, the development of medical devices
[
38
,
53
]
, and a general understanding of human physiology
[
11
,
45
]
. For example, Bruel
et al.
[
8
]
simulated a leg musculoskeletal model driven by a reflex-based gait controller and observed how walking changed when various neural and biomechanical impairments were introduced in simulation. This approach allowed the authors to investigate the potential causes of pathological toe and heel gaits commonly observed in patients with spinal injury, stroke and cerebral palsy. Similarly, Elisha
et al.
[
15
]
developed a neuromechanical model of the esophagus to replicate Repetitive Antegrade Contractions and understand Esophageal Motility Disorders. Neuromechanical models can also be used for individualized medicine where models are constrained by a particular patient’s physiological recordings (
e.g.
, EMG data)
[
38
,
53
]

Outlook
Neuromechanically accurate animal digital twins are emerging as an integrative tool for linking neural circuits, biomechanics, and behavior. Concurrently, rapid progress in connectomics, population physiological recording, and high-performance computing is dramatically expanding the data and approaches available to constrain such models. In this context, we outline several promising research directions that we envision for the future.
First, more realistic models will be generated. Increasingly detailed whole-body scans and advances in soft-body simulation will make it possible to represent muscles, tendons, compliant tissues, and soft materials with greater fidelity. For neural controllers, recently acquired and upcoming connectomics datasets will impose strong topological constraints on the architecture of simulated networks. At the same time, large-scale simulation of more realistic neurons
[
16
,
40
]
—constrained by recordings of large neuronal populations—will help bridge the gap between network structure and function. These advances will also facilitate the development of individualized digital twins that capture the unique morphology and physiology of specific animals or humans, enabling personalized predictions for rehabilitation and clinical interventions.
Second, we expect that neuromechanical digital twins will become not just an interpretive tool, but a key step in the experimental pipeline itself. Real-time simulations informed by ongoing measurements will enable closed-loop experimentation. In this way, variables inferred from the model can be used to adaptively guide experimental conditions, analogous to how smart microscopy currently uses online image analysis to steer data acquisition. This approach will allow researchers to efficiently target previously hard-to-access states, explore rare but important behaviors, and—to some extent—perturb the system outside of its normal operating states, thereby steering data collection toward the most informative experiments. In the more distant future, simulation-in-the-loop experimentation has the potential to fundamentally change the design of neuroscience studies, shifting the field from
post hoc
analysis of experimental data (though the experiment itself might involve artificial perturbations) to active probing of brain-body-environment interactions, aided by a digital twin in parallel.
Third, a key promise of neuromechanical digital twins is the opportunity to identify and explore generalizable principles of sensorimotor control. Comparative studies across species will likely reveal recurring motifs in control architectures (
e.g.
, hierarchical versus decentralized), sensorimotor strategies (
e.g.
, feedforward versus feedback), mechanical strategies (
e.g.
, passive dynamics, soft material properties), and scaling laws (
e.g.
, across different body sizes, number of kinematic chains, and kinematic chain lengths). Achieving this will require studying broader and more diverse sets of naturalistic behaviors beyond stereotyped laboratory tasks, and possibly diversifying the study of animal ethology beyond common laboratory animals. The resulting hypotheses can then be tested
in silico
and possibly implemented in physical robots to validate neuroscientific insights and inspire the design of next-generation embodied artificial intelligence systems
[
52
]
.
Ultimately, realizing this exciting future will depend on sustained interdisciplinary exchange and shared infrastructure: faster and more accurate simulation engines, more efficient and affordable pipelines to construct body models, and interoperable software stacks. These needs reveal an underappreciated alignment across research and development domains with vastly diverging goals but shared technical challenges, spanning computer graphics (efficient simulation and rendering), cinematic animation and video gaming (realistic and controllable characters), sports and athletic science (individualized biomechanical models), human-computer interaction and virtual/augmented reality (closed-loop experimentation)—in addition to more conventional targets of collaboration such as machine learning (neural architectures and optimization), control theory (system identification and stability), and industrial digital twins (real-time model updates).
Concurrently, more detailed categorization of body mechanical properties (
e.g.
, joint actuation, compliant materials, sensors and actuators) and neuronal properties (
e.g.
, more diverse connectomics datasets) is necessary to better constrain structural elements for the animal digital twins. Beyond mechanical characteristics, joint neural and behavioral recordings of real animals at high spatiotemporal resolution are also required to constrain time-varying, dynamical processes that generate and regulate movement. Together, these developments will enable neuromechanical models to evolve from specialized tools into a general framework for studying behavior. By embedding grounded experimental observations in transparent and fully controllable digital twins, neuromechanical modeling offers a powerful platform for generating hypotheses, guiding experiments, and uncovering general principles of behavior control.

preview_text:
Animal behavior reflects interactions between the nervous system, body, and environment. Therefore, biomechanics and environmental context must be considered to dissect algorithms for behavioral control. This is enabled by leveraging neuromechanical digital twins: computational models that embed artificial neural controllers within realistic body models in simulated environments. Here we review advances in the creation and use of neuromechanical digital twins while also highlighting emerging opportunities for the future. First, we illustrate how neuromechanical models allow researchers to infer hidden biophysical variables that may be difficult to measure experimentally. Additionally, by perturbing these models, one can generate new experimentally testable hypotheses. Next, we explore how neuromechanical twins have been used to foster a deeper exchange between neuroscience, robotics, and machine learning. Finally, we show how neuromechanical twins can advance healthcare. We envision that coupling studies on animals with active probing of their neuromechanical twins will greatly accelerate neuroscientific discovery.

The embodied brain: Bridging the brain, body, and behavior with neuromechanical digital twins
